Description: Scarab carved from light brown steatite; back well defined with detailed clypeus, prothorax and elytra marked by single incised lines; small triangle on elytra at junction with prothorax on each side; at side, well-shaped legs with undercut triangle and projecting shelf underneath running round beetle; underside incised with central cross pattern motif flanked by symmetrically arranged twisted ribbons; pierced longitudinally.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the National Museum of Scotland. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The design of central twisted rope is particularly popular during the Second Intermediate Period (see examples from good contexts of the 13th-15th dynasty at Meggido, Jericho, Fara and especially Tell el-Ajjul: Tufnell 1984, 126, class 6C2, pl. XXVII; see also: Magnarini 2004, 189-190, nos. 06.07-06.08). The presence of such an early type of scarab in Naukratis can be interpreted in many ways: heirloom, brought from a nearby site in antiquity or by sebakhin, archaizing copy of the 25th or 26th dynasty… (on the various early scarabs from Naukratis see: Masson forthcoming). For a close motif on a stone scarab from Naukratis: Bristol, City Art Gallery & Museum H5115.9. Magnarini, F. 2004. Catalogo ragionato di una collezione di Scarabeo-Sigillo Egizi, BAR International Series 1241. Masson, A. forthcoming, ‘Egyptian Naukratis: the early evidence’, in A. Wodzińska (ed.), Delta and Sinai Current research, Proceedings of the conference in the University of Warsaw, Warsaw, April 25-27 2013. Tufnell, O. 1984, Studies on Scarab Seals, II: Scarab Seals and their Contribution to History in the Early Second Millennium BC, Warminster.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OA.39) (phase 3)
